description: From Middle English rei, reh, reoh, from Old English hrēoh (“rough, fierce, wild, angry, disturbed, troubled, stormy, tempestuous”), from Proto-Germanic *hreuhaz (“bad, wild”), from Proto-Indo-European *krewh₂- (“raw meat, fresh blood”).

Cognate with Scots ree, rae, ray (“ree”), Old Saxon hrē (“evil, bad, angry”), Gothic 𐌹𐌽𐍂𐌰𐌿𐌷𐍄𐌾𐌰𐌽 (inrauhtjan, “to become angry, rage against”). Related to Old English hrēaw (“raw, uncooked”). More at raw.

adjectives.description: ree (comparative reer or more ree, superlative reest or most ree)

entries.meaning: (Now chiefly dialectal) Wild; fierce; outrageous; overexcited; frenzied; delirious; crazy.
(Now chiefly dialectal) Befuddled with liquor; half-drunk; tipsy.
(Now chiefly dialectal) A state of befuddlement; intoxication.
(Now chiefly dialectal) A state of great excitement or frenzy.

verbs.description: ree (third-person singular simple present rees, present participle reeing, simple past and past participle reed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, now chiefly dialectal) To become extremely excited; fly into a rage.
(transitive, now chiefly dialectal) To drive into a state of excitement; fire with enthusiasm.

verbs.description: ree (third-person singular simple present rees, present participle reeing, simple past and past participle reed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, dialect) To riddle; to sift; to separate or throw off.

description: Probably from a rebracketing of ea with Old English þære, i.e. þære ēa becoming the ree.

entries.meaning: (obsolete or Essex dialect) A small river or stream.
examples: The church of this pariſh, vulgarly called St. Mary Overy, from its dedication to the virgin Mary, and ſituation over the Ree or river, in reſpect of London, is a ſtately Gothic ſtructure, in the form of a cathedral.
